BFA11E9555B144CABA1C530A5C66D6A2.description: Explain how changes in the physical environment and political environment influence changes in economic activity within a region.

09696A4F9E7D4E8085F6B40A0565FC7D.description: Describe common characteristics of developed nations and compare variations in levels of development.

77F7F7B2BD0A4E5786DA700E666F71E7.description: Compare contemporary patterns of industrialization and development in selected regions of the world.

059D2B7A134A40DEBFF22EA5DA289498.description: Compare the impact of government policies in both market and command economic systems on the availability and use of natural resources and development.

C01E6C415B994DCA894E04D7B1057011.description: Examine the significance of access to natural resources, energy, and technological innovations (e.g., wind, solar, nuclear) to the economic development of a region.

BC87950C47FC4D5C89650C0163B050A8.description: The student will analyze the impact of industrialization on economic development.

362293FE47E54A00B8FFACDC0A66C675.description: Analyze the influence of geography on current issues to consider decisions regarding future land use, including the costs and benefits of environmental regulation.

5B46D6116B4546AF859BBF2A292A2E89.description: Explain how transportation improvements (e.g., aqueducts, canals, railroad systems, airports) impacted human development through modification of the environment.

02EC06F9F4284F19BF295B070D13EB3A.description: Examine the impact of agricultural practices (e.g., irrigation, levees, terraced farming, crop rotation, artesian wells, conservation, water resource management, and deforestation) on the environment and quality of life.

79BE7479F5F143CF8F36B087C5C70953.description: Describe the characteristics of modern commercial agriculture including major production regions, variations within major zones, and the effects of markets.

0F1FF47C37834F2A9425FF8102F5383D.description: Analyze settlement patterns associated with major agricultural regions and linkages among regions of food production and consumption.

2D64445EE8E04E5EAF293EEFD07462BA.description: Examine how different civilizations have sought to improve the well-being of their people by modifying or adapting to their environments.

D39AB6383B724E19959DB69BE046BD48.description: The student will analyze patterns of land use among the worldâ€™s people.

70EA22A5B3DD4C94B54A70719D898BB2.description: Explain how international alliance networks respond to changing needs of people, places, and regions.

BD1644697604496AB5DDCB773C6B3C78.description: Evaluate how the forces of cooperation and conflict among people influence the control and management of territory and resources.

17A8D334F6BD4C6D90049559535630A6.description: Examine changes and challenges to political/territorial arrangements, by describing the forces that shape the worldâ€™s contemporary political map, including the rise or devolution of nation-states.

AB779AB573FD43B38DC6E3AF61BE3702.description: Compare the worldâ€™s political systems of government, based on limited versus unlimited authority, including the rights and opportunities of citizens within each system.

D790FB0FD4EB430C922B4F3092A2FB9C.description: Analyze the nature and meaning of territorial boundaries and their influence on identity, interaction, and exchange.

F8F2D5B25B184841AB5633B1CC084E43.description: The student will explain the political organization of space.

A00F896B21BF4A6CA284DE6B3A97263A.description: Explain the processes of cultural diffusion and interdependence, analyzing their impact on defining a region.

6D1552D8DE2C4C0389F013644BE332D4.description: Analyze the role of the environment in influencing a regionâ€™s culture.

B83583212EA04D1E8AE590812DAEF03E.description: Describe and draw conclusions about the spatial dimensions of culture as defined by language, religion, and ethnicity.

7AE78F66086C485EA13596D3F9004645.description: Compare the worldâ€™s major cultural landscapes to analyze cultural differences, cultural identity, social mores, and sets of beliefs which determine a sense of place.

DA24686E7DFB440E84CF20EB9CEDF7B7.description: The student will analyze the components and regional variations of cultural patterns and processes.

83EDB1FDD02B46DFA65A7B37F0C4D32E.description: Explain the push and pull theory of migration and its impact on human capital and demographic transitions, including the consequences of major voluntary and involuntary migrations.

ACE8949BDA3D44289D626D9722A7BF31.description: Examine common characteristics of urban versus rural communities, including the patterns and impact of modern migration to urban centers and megacities.

B01E2F83CD5E48658709F69E4A605103.description: Interpret geographic data measuring population including density, distribution, patterns of composition, and population trends and projections to analyze issues related to population change.

FDCD0EB6B7AC4DBB8EE1A848F2B0C134.description: The student will analyze how the human population is organized geographically in order to understand how change affects human systems.

BDE7C69C10D842F6A96432C366D1AA17.description: Utilize geographic technologies and geographical data including census data and imagery to draw conclusions about the influence of geography on the worldâ€™s people and places.

9CD71F0A78D34ED2A09600AD14B46D37.description: Define regions and analyze changing interconnections among places, using historical and contemporary examples.

C129F71028FB4D499EE3A35041F2085B.description: Utilize geographic skills to understand and analyze the spatial organization of people, places, and environments on the Earthâ€™s surface.

3F6C17ABD7DE4062ACDCE97E65BFCD85.description: Analyze key concepts underlying the geographical perspectives of location, space, place, scale, pattern, regionalization, and globalization.

B508586625E548C5A45E96F26BCAF72C.description: The student will use maps and other geographic representations, tools and technologies to acquire, process, and solve problems from a spatial perspective.

71E5DA3DF22443A587BA955B90FA7131.description: Construct presentations or products for a designated audience, using research and reasoning to enhance understanding of a topic or issue.

8372C846AE7A4B9D906ABDB64F919FB1.description: Integrate quotes and summaries of research findings into written products while avoiding plagiarism.

8D2B7D72B451474EA7AC7DB78D27CD4D.description: Develop self-generated theses or claims related to independent research and investigations using credible and relevant sources.

3922BEA2936E40DF897341250D709DC2.description: Engage in authentic research to acquire, refine, and share knowledge through written presentations and products.

2CE2E106B56A4D6BB2332F790ABD4D99.description: Compose argumentative written products, including a precise claim as distinguished from opposing claims, organizing logical reasoning, and providing credible evidence to develop an argument.

40277640C9214A7D8032833155DA467D.description: Compose informative essays and written products, developing a thesis, citing and incorporating evidence from multiple sources and maintaining an organized, formal structure.

D5DBEFF583E348C8985BC4C980E560F3.description: Summarize and paraphrase, integrate evidence, and cite sources to create written products, research projects, and presentations for multiple purposes related to social studies content.

AC2F502755D24F3A84B3187147D41E48.description: The student will develop a variety of evidence- based written products designed for multiple purposes.

AD5E15708D4E472E93B70F361549E866.description: Actively listen, evaluate, and analyze a speakerâ€™s message, asking questions while engaged in collaborative discussions about social studies topics and texts.

E7A592B12B42454B88F1173AEB03AFCA.description: Evaluate the authorâ€™s point of view, potential bias, and how authors can reach different conclusions regarding the same issue.

C08AF1FC5FDA4B65BA88F4CC50C415CB.description: Evaluate the extent to which historical or cultural perspectives affect an authorâ€™s stated or implied purpose.

2F88CC5FAA2C4536A9BD0BF5A2F5A28E.description: Apply critical reading and thinking skills to interpret, evaluate, and respond to a variety of complex texts and perspectives.

410E045FF533466286F46EBAFF37CD34.description: Analyze information from visual, oral, digital, and interactive texts (e.g., maps, charts, images, political cartoons, videos, artwork) in order to draw conclusions and defend arguments.

DE1152B7A3B64C268471A1CFEE254516.description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, evaluating features such as author, date, and origin of information.

4E21F367F36148FF9BB52F584E319ADD.description: Comprehend, evaluate, and synthesize textual sources to acquire and refine knowledge in the social studies.

E0D8ED85359642E78E95AA3E339538F8.description: The student will engage in critical, active reading of primary and secondary sources related to social studies concepts.

18DF0FBDD1084C698EB2EA0CDB11097F.description: Evaluate the impact, both intended and unintended, of government policies on market outcomes at national and global levels, past and present.

A7FDD813BA004194856966F841FD9A00.description: Construct arguments using a combination of evidence regarding solutions used by nations to address historical or contemporary economic issues.

BF9149EB61ED4A5A87AE5562104AA03F.description: Evaluate economic data from charts and graphs, noting trends and making predictions.

E4EB0197EECB4BCD86B9B8D90826EE53.description: Identify the principles of economic systems and develop an understanding of the benefits of a market system in local, national, and global settings.

7556D655319949C1A1CFCA8D9069DFD7.description: Evaluate the extent to which political and economic decisions have had significant impact on human and physical environments of various places and regions.

42DCE6E667CA4D67970478ABE539F3CA.description: Compare and analyze complex maps and mapping technologies to analyze spatial patterns of human and physical environments, explaining relationships between the environment and events, past and present.

41B0846DDED3491E8EA7875BB6FD2358.description: Actively engage in asking and answering geographic questions by acquiring, organizing, and analyzing multiple sources of data and information about the worldâ€™s past and present.

BD14EE33A5EF4D96BBA588C287DD7644.description: Demonstrate a mastery of geographic concepts and the use of geographic tools to understand the impact of geography on the past and present.

F84D90E04C3D4CCC995528B068D8AB96.description: Evaluate how multiple, complex events are shaped by unique circumstances of time and place; construct and interpret parallel timelines.

C9936D2BB2FB4AFAAEF2A6E7CB4E8F98.description: Analyze complex and interacting factors that influence multiple perspectives during different historical eras and contemporary events.

A352469607324D2D93BC368FDFC42D96.description: Gather and evaluate the usefulness of various formats of evidence for specific inquiry, analyzing the broader historical context, and assessing potential bias and credibility of sources.

BB401B1EDB0B41AF8B64F3326CE2989B.description: Develop skills which demonstrate an understanding of historical events and the people who shaped our history.

0E130F13FE804247B715F4031C7F4061.description: Analyze the impact of constitutions, laws, treaties, and international agreements, by comparing how various governmental powers and responsibilities have changed over time.

A8327EC181C84ECB96CAA940EF14D7BB.description: Evaluate the impact of the structure and powers exercised by governmental systems on public policy, using historical and contemporary examples.

5BB5B9B9F96549F3B5A0B4DBC0DF7099.description: Evaluate various significant documents from the United States and other nations to compare civic virtues and principles of political systems.

D2875B085EF94E1B90B7402C92D81CAC.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of government, the benefits of democratic systems, and their responsibilities as citizens.

536966FA84E649F7BD58974E5BC58455.description: The student will use interdisciplinary tools to acquire, apply, and evaluate content understanding of the four strands of social studies.

6D9D75EAD00C489BA598517B77D93A23.description: Demonstrate understanding of content through the development of self-driven inquiries and the completion of multi-staged, authentic tasks and assessments.

450C8D948A3F4D27A4C8286F845C7421.description: Reinforce critical thinking by evaluating and challenging ideas and assumptions, analyzing and explaining inconsistencies in reasoning.

ECEA2CF9838D4E6096B2C3CA21C251EB.description: Evaluate points of agreement and disagreement from reliable information and expert interpretations used to answer supporting questions related to content knowledge.

D9FBA647035342E5912274F5FE792275.description: Develop, investigate, and evaluate plausible answers to essential questions that reflect enduring understandings across time, real world circumstances, and social studies disciplines.

A242162738504DA09D42FC0CBDA1429C.description: Develop practices which demonstrate an understanding that social studies involves the evaluation of evidence.

199D9E46B77D44CEB722DA435A630FC5.description: Gather and evaluate information regarding complex problems, assessing individual and collective actions taken to address them.

62DB772D6183450F84FA339682FE2334.description: Engage in a range of deliberative and democratic processes to develop strategies to address authentic, real-world problems in community and out-of-school contexts.

D7EE7121C87244819BEC455A7CD9C9CF.description: Evaluate the impact of perspectives, civil discourse, and democratic principles on addressing civic issues.

129FF979617347E3A23D4F4B5663DE69.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the virtue of civil discourse to analyze and address real- world problems.

BFE8E1FE97944BF282D55F43EB4AA3D8.description: The student will apply critical thinking skills to address authentic civic issues.
